docs.lead_paragraph: Despite widespread belief among both doctors and lay people that cerebral palsy results from lack of oxygen to the baby's brain during labor and delivery, a new report says that birth asphyxia alone accounts for 10 percent of cases at most. The study found that the vast majority of children who develop cerebral palsy experience prenatal problems, including maternal infections, clotting disorders and strokes, that damage the developing brain long before labor begins.

headline.main: Refuting 'Myth,' Study Finds Most Cerebral Palsy Predates Labor

docs.abstract: Study finds that vast majority of children who develop cerebral palsy experience prenatal problems that damage developing brain long before labor begins and that contrary to widespread belief, only 10 percent of cases, at most, are due to lack of oxygen to baby's brain during labor and delivery; findings are compiled by expert panel convened by American Academy of Pediatrics and American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, which has been concerned about growing unwillingness of doctors to practice obstetrics because of litigation risks, skyrocketing jury awards and soaring rates of malpractice insurance (M)
docs.snippet: Despite widespread belief among both doctors and lay people that cerebral palsy results from lack of oxygen to the baby's brain during labor and delivery, a new report says that birth asphyxia alone accounts for 10 percent of cases at most.    The...

keywords.value: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OBSTETRICIANS AND GYNECOLOGISTS

docs.lead_paragraph: Thirty-three years after New York became the first state to repeal the ban against abortion, it is emerging as the latest battleground over reproductive rights, with city and state lawmakers divided over whether emergency contraceptives should be made widely available to women. These contraceptives, also known as the ''morning-after pill,'' are concentrated doses of birth control pills that can prevent pregnancy by stopping an egg from becoming fertilized or by stopping a fertilized egg from becoming implanted in the uterus.
docs.abstract: New York State lawmakers are being heavily lobbied to address availability of so-called morning-after pill, which prevents pregnancy if taken within 72 hours after intercourse; Assembly is expected to pass legislation allowing women to obtain pill without prescription and has already passed bill that would require hospitals to provide them to rape victims; fate of both bills remains uncertain in Republican-dominated Senate; New York City health officials express concern about cost of programs to cash-strapped city (M)
docs.snippet: Thirty-three years after New York became the first state to repeal the ban against abortion, it is emerging as the latest battleground over reproductive rights, with city and state lawmakers divided over whether emergency contraceptives should be...

docs.lead_paragraph: The chance to see white-haired women reminiscing about the sexual mores of their youth during the 1950's may not be the first thing you would look forward to in a film about the birth-control pill, but it's the most engaging aspect of Chana Gazit's hourlong documentary on this ever-fascinating subject, to be shown tonight on ''American Experience'' on PBS. Loretta McLaughlin, a Roman Catholic historian, recalls a priest telling a group of married women that if they used contraceptives, ''the faces of their unborn children would haunt them on their deathbeds.''

headline.main: A Reproductive Revolution And Those Who Lived It

docs.abstract: Laura Miller reviews The Pill, American Experience television show on birth-control pill; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Bill Frist's Prescription'' (editorial, Feb. 19) described a potential ban on abortion as a ban on ''late-term abortion.'' It also included Senator Bill Frist's declaration that the procedure was ''outside the practice of medicine today.'' What is really outside the practice of medicine is the use of terms like ''late-term abortion.'' In fact, the bill as written would outlaw some of the safest and most common methods of abortion used throughout a woman's pregnancy, as early as 10 weeks in some cases.

keywords.value: PLANNED PARENTHOOD OF NEW YORK CITY

docs.lead_paragraph: GIVEN the startling amount of hand-wringing and expense that goes into wedding gowns, some marvel that the relevant life span of those silk and tulle confections seems only slightly longer than that of the foam atop a cappuccino. Social convention dictates that the gowns are never to be seen again on the original wearer, a notion that grated against the romantic and practical sensibilities of a group of married San Francisco women. They put on their old wedding dresses and wore them to the Ritz-Carlton hotel on Nob Hill on Feb. 8 for what they billed as their first annual ''Wear It Again'' party.

headline.main: Wedding Day Nostalgia For That Same Old Dress

docs.abstract: Dozen women, ranging in age from 26 to 58 and decked out in their old wedding gowns, hold first annual Wear It Again party at Ritz-Carlton Hotel in San Francisco; photo (M)
